English: Do you think it's unfair that perpetrators of school violence, like celebrities these days, are later revealed and suffer?
how is it?

Korean: 지금 아예 생업이 중단되는 거 보면 그 사람들도 또 다시 피해자가 되는 거 같긴 한데 그래도 본인이 한 일에 대해서 그렇게 된 거니까 어느 정도는 감수해야 하는 것 같아.
English: Seeing that their livelihoods have come to a halt now, it seems like those people are becoming victims again, but I think they should accept it to some extent because it is something they did.
What do you think?

Korean: 응 나도 가해자들이 어렸을 때 처벌 안 받은 걸 커서 받는다고 생각하면 억울해 하지 말고 반성하는 게 먼저 인 거 같아!
English: Yeah, I also think that if you think that the perpetrators were not punished when they were young and are punished when they grow up, you shouldn't feel wronged, but reflect on your actions first!

Korean: 요즘은 하도 문제가 많아서 더 그렇게 생각하게 되는 거 같아
English: I think I think that way more these days because there are so many problems.

Korean: 맞아 본인이 한 일을 반성하는 게 먼저가 아니고  자기도 피해자라고 주장하니까 그게 더 문제야!
English: That's right. The problem is that instead of reflecting on what you did, you claim that you are also a victim!

Korean: 근데 그 사람들을 옹호하는 사람들도 또 있더라

Korean: 맞아 여러 가지 문제가 또 생기는 거 같아
English: Yeah, I think it creates a lot of problems again

English: I hope that in the future, there will be clear legal solutions to resolve this issue!
I hope something gets resolved quickly.

English: Have you seen the articles about the democracy movement in Myanmar these days?

Yeah, it was really bad

Korean: 그러게 진짜 그거 보고  한국 기사들도 그렇고 우리 5. 18 때 같다고 그러던데!
English: That's right, after seeing that, Korean reporters also said that it was similar to our May 18th incident!

Korean: 그렇게 영상 보니까 진짜 비슷하더라고 국제사회에서 빨리  도와줬으면 좋겠는데 선뜻 나서지 못하고 있는 거 같아
English: When I watched the video, it was really similar. I wish the international community would help quickly, but it seems they are reluctant to step forward.

Korean: 맞아 아무래도 그 국가 안에서 해결해야 하는 게 맞으니까 ㅠ 그리고 말도 안 듣는 거 같던데 거기 정부에서
English: Yes, I think it's right to resolve it within that country. And I don't think the government there will listen to me.
Yeah, it was a total dictatorship.

Korean: 우리나라 80년대랑 너무 비슷하게 흘러가는 거 같아
English: I feel like it's flowing very similarly to the 80s in our country.
This needs to be resolved quickly, you know?

English: Yeah, Southeast Asia seems a bit dictatorial!
Was Thailand communist too?

English: Well, Thailand has a king, so isn't it different from communism?
Ah, there's a king. It's unfamiliar!

Korean: 시위 얘기하다 보니까  요즘에 코로나 때문에  노 마스크 운동도 일어나고 있대
English: Speaking of protests, I heard that there is also a no-mask movement happening these days due to the coronavirus.

Korean: 노 마스크 운동이라니 너무 위험한 거 같은데 그 사람들은 코로나를 안 믿는 거야?
English: The no-mask movement seems so dangerous. Do those people not believe in corona?

Korean: 자기는 안 써도 안 걸린다고 그렇게  생각하나 봐

English: That's a shame, I've become interested in interior design lately.
Do you like decorating your home?

Korean: 오늘의 집 앱에서 장 스탠드 하나 샀는데 집안 분위기가 바뀌더라고요.
English: I bought a shelf stand from the Today's Home app and the atmosphere of my house changed.

Korean: 오늘의 집 저도 깔아 놓고 가끔 구경하는데 저도 빨리 자취 시작해서 집 꾸며보고 싶네요.
English: I also have today's house set up and look at it sometimes, but I also want to start living alone soon and decorate my house.

Korean: 취향에 맞는 가구가 늘어가는 게 재미있어요,
English: It's fun to see the number of furniture that suits my taste increasing.

Korean: 집은 회색이랑 원목 색이 많아야 예뻐 보이더라고요.
English: I think a house looks prettier when it has a lot of gray and wood tones.

Korean: 저는 완전 흰색이나 새빨간 색 섞어서 흰빨로 꾸며보고 싶어요.
English: I want to try decorating it with a mix of completely white and bright red.
Decorating it extravagantly is also a good idea.

Korean: 근데 정작 지금 방은 방음재 때문에 너무 칙칙해서 다 뜯어 버리고 싶어요.
English: But right now, the room is so gloomy because of the soundproofing material that I want to tear it all out.

Korean: 방음재 있으면 방이 되게 덥지 않아요?
English: If there's soundproofing material, doesn't the room get really hot?

Korean: 방음재 있다고 해서 덥진 않은데 그냥 목소리가 흡수되는 느낌 들어요.
English: It's not that it's hot because there's soundproofing, but it just feels like the sound is being absorbed.
As for the interior, it's the worst.

Korean: 그러면 반대쪽에서 오는 소리도 거의 안 들어오나요?
English: Then you can hardly hear any sound coming from the other side?
What's that sound coming from the other side?

Korean: 소리가 엄청 깨끗하게 들리는 거예요. 안 튕기고
English: The sound is incredibly clear. There is no skipping.

Korean: 방 밖에서 들리는 소리를 말하는 거예요.
English: I'm talking about sounds heard outside the room.
Are you interested in cars?

Korean: 관심이 별로 없어서 저는 차 종류를 잘 몰라요.
English: I don't know much about different types of cars because I'm not really interested in them.

Korean: 저도 차에 대해서는 잘 몰라서 친구들이 맨날 차 얘기해도 못 껴요.
English: I don't know much about cars, so I can't join in even when my friends talk about cars all the time.

Korean: 저는 평생 대중교통 타고 다닐 생각이에요.
English: I plan to take public transportation for the rest of my life.

Korean: 나중에 어쨌든 운전하긴 하셔야 될 텐데 괜찮으시겠어요?
English: You'll have to drive later anyway, is that okay?

Korean: 나중에는 더 대중교통이 발달할 텐데 그럴 필요가 있을까요?
English: In the future, public transportation will be more developed, but will it be necessary?
Won't only Seoul develop?

Korean: 그 전에 우리나라 없어질 거 같긴 한데
English: Before that, it seemed like our country would disappear
If Seoul develops, I will have to live in Seoul for the rest of my life.
You have to work hard to earn money.

Korean: 전 주변에서 아직도 차 없는 게 저 하나뿐이라 요즘 차 생각이 많이 들어요.
English: I'm the only one around me who doesn't have a car, so I've been thinking about cars a lot these days.

Korean: 차를 일찍 사면 돈을 못 모은다는 말도 있더라고요.
English: There's also a saying that if you buy a car early, you won't be able to save money.
I'm not sure if a car is really necessary.

Korean: 일찍 사든 늦게 사든 못 모으긴 해요.
English: Whether you buy early or late, you can't collect them.

Korean: 전 동네에 버스도 한 대 밖에 없어요.
English: There's only one bus in my neighborhood.
Then it would be very inconvenient.

Korean: 동네 안에서도 불편해 죽겠는데 타지로 출퇴근하려니까 다 부숴버리고 싶네요.
English: I'm so uncomfortable in my own neighborhood, but when I commute to work in another city, I feel like I want to tear everything down.
Then you probably don't even have a license

Korean: 네, 저는 면허가 없어서 전동 킥보드도 못 타는 신세예요.
English: Yes, I don't have a driver's license, so I can't even ride an electric kickboard.

Korean: 아 전동 킥보드도 면허 있어야 해요?
English: Oh, do I need a license to ride an electric kickboard too?
Electric motor license?

Korean: 네, 이제 법이 바뀌어서 전동기 면허나 운전 면허 있어야 탈 수 있더라고요.
English: Yes, the law has changed now so you need a motorcycle license or a driver's license to ride one.

Korean: 아르바이트 제일 길게 해보신 게 어떤 거예요?
English: What is the longest part-time job you've had?

Korean: 편의점 아르바이트 1년 넘게 했었던 거 같아요.
English: I think I worked part-time at a convenience store for over a year.

Korean: 저도 편의점 1년 피시방 1년 했던 게 제일 길었는데 다른 건 뭐 해본 거 없으신가요?
English: I also worked at a convenience store for one year and a PC room for another year, which was the longest I've worked in, but have you done anything else?

Korean: 주차 유도, 한식당, 택배 등등 짧게는 여러 가지 했었어요.
English: I've done a variety of things in short, like guiding parking, running a Korean restaurant, and delivering packages.

Korean: 저는 공장 몇 개랑 서비스업 밖에 안 해봤는데 여러 가지 많이 해보셨네요.
English: I've only worked in a few factories and service industries, but you've done a lot of different things.
Did you load and unload the truck as a delivery worker?

Korean: 얼마 전에 친구가 쿠팡에 가서 되게 쉬운 일했다고 해서 갔는데 저는 잘못 걸려서 그냥 상하차를 했어요.
English: A while ago, a friend of mine went to Coupang and said it was really easy, so I went, but I got on the wrong train and just got on and off.

Korean: 친구분도 상하차했는데 재능이 있어서 쉬웠던 건 아닐까요?
English: My friend also got on and off the train, but wasn't it easy because he was talented?

Korean: 걔는 물건 레일에서 내려오는 거 분류를 했더라고요.
English: He was sorting things coming down from the rails.
Was it easy to get on and off?
That day I realized how heavy wet tissues were.
Then what about water instead of wet tissues?

Korean: 저 맨날 생수 시켜 먹는데 물류센터 고생이 많으시겠네요.
English: I order bottled water every day, so the distribution center must be having a hard time.

Korean: 물은 진짜 너무 무거울 거 같은데...
English: Water seems really heavy...

Korean: 어쩔 수 없이 저도 시켜 먹어요.
English: I have no choice but to order it too.

Korean: 저희 회사 계약 기간이 11월 말일까지 맞죠?
English: Our company's contract period ends at the end of November, right?

Korean: 네, 11월 말 이후에는 어디로 취업해야 하나 걱정이네요.
English: Yes, I'm worried about where to find a job after the end of November.

Korean: 저도 최대한 공백 없이 일해야 할 텐데 걱정이네요.
English: I'm worried that I'll have to work without any gaps as much as possible.
Aren't you interested in broadcasting training?

Korean: 아직 잘 알아보지 않아서 모르겠는데 타이밍이 맞는다면 나쁘지 않은 것 같아요.
English: I don't know because I haven't looked into it yet, but if the timing is right, it doesn't seem like a bad idea.

Korean: 군 생활 때 보직이 어떻게 되셨었어요?
English: What was your position during your military service?
I was a battalion personnel administrative soldier.

Korean: 인사 행정병은 훈련 다 참여하는 건가요
English: Do all personnel officers participate in training?

Korean: 참모부라서 거의 다 참여하고 업무도 해야 해서 얼굴에 위장크림 바르고 컴퓨터 앞에서 일하는 경우도 많죠.
English: Since it's a staff office, almost everyone has to participate and do work, so there are many cases where I put camouflage cream on my face and work in front of the computer.

Korean: 아 고생하셨네요. 야근도 하고 그러셨나요 그럼
English: Oh, you must have had a hard time. Did you work overtime too?

Korean: 아마 일과 시간 이후에 제일 많이 불려간 게 저일 거예요.
English: I'm probably the one who gets called out the most after work hours.
Are the administrative soldiers just chosen at random?

Korean: 처음에는 전투 중대로 들어갔다가 행정병이 새로 안 들어와서 뽑혔어요.
English: At first, I joined a combat unit, but then I was selected because there were no new administrative soldiers coming in.

Korean: 저는 군 생활 내내 편하게 지내다 와서 군대 얘기하면 별로 할 얘기가 없어요.
English: I lived comfortably throughout my military service, so I don't have much to say when it comes to military life.

Korean: 저도 몸이 엄청 힘들지는 않았는데 너무 일을 많이 해서 디스크가 생겼어요.
English: My body wasn't that tired, but I worked too much and got a herniated disc.

Korean: 그게 몸이 엄청 힘든 거 아니에요?
English: Isn't that incredibly hard on your body?

Korean: 군대는 병만 안 얻어오면 성공한 거 같아요.
English: I think the military is successful as long as they don't get sick.

Korean: 안 좋은 의자에 오래 앉아 있었나 봐요.
English: I think I've been sitting in a bad chair for too long.

Korean: 저는 가서 제가 생각보다 정상인이라는 생각을 얻어왔어요.
English: I went and came away feeling like I was more normal than I thought.

Korean: 진짜 어떻게 현역 왔는지 궁금해지는 사람들 엄청 많긴 하죠.
English: There are a lot of people who are really curious about how I became an active soldier.

Korean: 하루 종일 족구만 해도 월급 받는 간부들도 있는데요, 뭐
English: There are executives who get paid just for playing foot volleyball all day long.

Korean: 뭐 큰 사건은 없었나요? 군대 있을 때
English: Were there any major incidents while you were in the military?
There was a time when a person died.

Korean: 수사 속기 자격증을 따야 할지 고민이에요.
English: I'm wondering if I should get a stenography certificate.

Korean: 난이도가 한글 속기에 비해서 쉬우니까 내년에 가벼운 마음으로 따면 되지 않을까요?
English: Since the difficulty level is easier than Korean shorthand, wouldn't it be okay to take it lightly next year?

Korean: 올해는 코로나 때문에 시험 한 번밖에 없었는데 내년에는 더 있었으면 좋겠네요.
English: There was only one test this year due to COVID, but I hope there will be more next year.

Korean: 저는 수사 속기 3급을 땄는데 내년에는 더 높은 급수가 가능할 것 같아요.
English: I passed the 3rd level of investigative shorthand, and I think I can pass a higher level next year.

Korean: 솔직히 이제 2급 딸 수 있을 거 같아요. 이번에 전사 작업 한 거 때문에
English: Honestly, I think I can get a 2nd level now. Because of the transcription work I did this time.

Korean: 네, 맞아요. 그리고 따는 김에 1급도 한번 도전해 보려고요.
English: Yes, that's right. And while I'm at it, I'm going to try for level 1 as well.

Korean: 이번 한글 속기 시험은 준비 잘 되고 계신가요?
English: Are you preparing well for this Korean shorthand test?

Korean: 1급 정확도 85% 정도인데 할 수 있는 만큼 해봐야죠.
English: The accuracy of level 1 is around 85%, so you should try as much as you can.

Korean: 근데 2급 안정권이 항상 나오는 것도 아니라서 불안해요.
English: But I'm worried because I don't always get a level 2 stability.

Korean: 아예 실력 안 돼서 떨어지면 몰라도 당일 날 미끄러지면 진짜 아쉽더라고요.
English: It would be okay if I failed because I didn't have the skills, but it would be really disappointing if I slipped up on the day.

Korean: 올해 상반기에 긴장 너무해서 2급 떨어졌는데 시험 때만 되면 평소만큼 안 나오더라고요.
English: I was so nervous in the first half of this year that I failed level 2, and when it came time for the exam, I didn't do as well as usual.

Korean: 속기 시험은 컨디션이랑 운에 영향을 많이 받는 것 같아요.
English: I think the shorthand test is greatly affected by condition and luck.

Korean: 2급보다 1급이 내용이 더 쉬울 때도 있어서 주제만 쉬운 거 나왔으면 좋겠어요.
English: I wish only the easy topics were included, as the content of Level 1 is sometimes easier than that of Level 2.

Korean: 1급은 잠깐만 놓치면 훅 지나가서 집중력 관리가 중요한 거 같아요.
English: I think that level 1 is something that passes by quickly if you miss it for even a moment, so managing your concentration is important.

Korean: 맞아요 한번 멍하니 있으면 너무 많이 날아가요.
English: That's right, if you just sit there blankly for a moment, too much will fly away.

Korean: 저는 올해 시험은 포기해서 마음은 편하네요 그래도
English: I feel relieved that I gave up on taking the exam this year though.

Korean: 저는 최대한 빨리 자격증을 따 놓으려고요.
English: I want to get my license as soon as possible.
Aren't you interested in shorthand?

Korean: 필기 안보는 거면 괜찮을 것 같아요, 필기는 포기해야 할 게 너무 많아서
English: I think it would be okay if I didn't look at the notes, there are too many things I have to give up on.
By any chance, where are your parents from?
My father is from Chungcheong Province and my mother is from Jeolla Province.
Oh, my father is also from Chungcheong Province, haha
Down there is Chungnam
Are you on good terms with your family?

Korean: 전 동생이랑만 좀 서먹하고 어머니 아버지랑은 사이가 좋은 편이에요.
English: I'm a bit awkward with my younger sibling, but I get along well with my mom and dad.

Korean: 저는 사이가 좋은 사람은 없고 그냥 가끔 연락해요.
English: I don't have a close relationship with anyone, we just keep in touch occasionally.
So what is the atmosphere like when you get together with your family?
Everyone is at peace except me.

Korean: 저는 복잡한 게 싫어서 혼자 떨어져 있어요.
English: I hate complicated things, so I stay alone.

Korean: 그렇군요. 전 동생도 원래 사이가 좋았는데 우울증을 앓고 나서 성격이 변해서 대인 기피 같은 게 생겼어요.
English: I see. My younger sibling and I used to get along well, but after he got depressed, his personality changed and he became a bit of a social phobia.

Korean: 안타깝네요, 마음의 병은 어떻게 해야 할지 몰라서 가족들도 참 어려워 하실 거 같아요.
English: It's a shame, I think the family must be having a hard time because they don't know what to do about mental illness.

Korean: 네 그래서 동생만 특히 잘 못 지내는 중이에요.
English: Yes, that's why my younger brother is particularly having a hard time.
Are all your family members at your hometown now?

Korean: 아버지는 부산에 어머니는 부천에 동생은 공주에 저는 서울에 있어요.
English: My father is in Busan, my mother is in Bucheon, my younger sister is in Gongju, and I am in Seoul.
They are all scattered all over the place.
It must be difficult to get everyone together.

Korean: 네, 그래서 거의 명절 말고는 모일 일이 없어요.
English: Yes, so we rarely get together except for holidays.

Korean: 회사 계약 끝나면 한번 가족모임 추진해 보세요.
English: Once your company contract is over, try having a family reunion.

Korean: 그 전에 추석이라 한 번 모이지 않을까요?
English: Shouldn't we get together before Chuseok?

Korean: 여자친구 분은 만난 지 얼마나 되셨어요?
English: How long have you been seeing your girlfriend?
It's going to be our 2nd anniversary soon.
Even tomorrow is my girlfriend's birthday.

Korean: 그래서 선물이랑 서프라이즈는 어떤 걸 준비하셨나요
English: So what kind of gifts and surprises have you prepared?

Korean: 그냥 밥이나 한 끼 먹는 거죠, 뭐
English: Just eating a meal or something, you know.
As expected, you are sweet.
My girlfriend's birthday is in March so I still have some free time.

Korean: 여자친구가 시간이 없어서 아마 8월 말 지나면 놀러 다니지 싶은데 코로나 때문에 그것도 확실하지도 않네요.
English: My girlfriend doesn't have much time, so I'd like to go out and hang out after the end of August, but I'm not sure about that because of the coronavirus.
Did you say your girlfriend was studying?

Korean: 네, 경찰 준비하는데 잘 됐으면 좋겠네요.
English: Yes, I hope everything goes well with your preparation for the police exam.
Are you preparing starting this year?
I hope everything goes well.

Korean: 시험 한 번 봤었는데 경찰은 1년에 2번이니까 거의 1년 됐죠.
English: I took the test once, but the police test is given twice a year, so it's been almost a year.
Are you getting along well with your girlfriend?

Korean: 네. 저는 아직 80일밖에 안 돼서 잘 지내고 있어요.
English: Yes, I'm doing well, it's only been 80 days.
It's already been 100 days this month.
What would you like as a 100-day gift?

Korean: 닌텐도 갖고 싶다 그래서 닌텐도 샀는데 타격이 너무 크네요.
English: I wanted a Nintendo so I bought one, but it was a huge blow.

Korean: 그냥 다른 거 사주고 다시 팔까요?
English: Should I just buy something else and sell it again?
Is there anything better than Nintendo?
How much does Nintendo cost?

Korean: 정가가 34만 원이고 거기에 게임 타이틀이 8만 원이고 기타 액정필름이랑 이래저래 악세사리가 많네요
English: The regular price is 340,000 won, the game title is 80,000 won, and there are many accessories such as other liquid crystal films.

Korean: 근데 받으면 여자친구 분이 되게 좋아할 것 같아요.
English: But I think your girlfriend will really like it if you give it to her.

Korean: 혹시 주변에 특이한 동물 키우는 사람 없으신가요?
English: Is there anyone around you who raises an unusual animal?

Korean: 특이하지는 않지만 초등학교 때 앵무새 키우는 친구가 있었어요.
English: It's not unusual, but I had a friend in elementary school who had a parrot.

Korean: 저 앵무새 실제로 한번도 못 봐서 보고 싶어요.
English: I've never actually seen that parrot before, so I'd like to see it.

Korean: 몰랐는데 앵무새라고 다 말을 따라하지는 않는다 하더라고요.
English: I didn't know, but I heard that parrots don't repeat everything you say.

Korean: 그래요? 그것도 똑똑한 애들만 따라 하는 건가 보네요.
English: Really? I guess only smart kids follow that.
Is the parrot big?

Korean: 제 친구가 키우던 앵무새는 작았는데 큰 거는 되게 크더라고요.
English: My friend had a small parrot, but the big ones were really big.

Korean: 제 친구 중에 파충류 키우고 싶다고 맨날 이구아나랑 도마뱀 사진 보내던 놈 있었는데 지금은 키우고 있는지 모르겠네요.
English: I have a friend who used to send me pictures of iguanas and lizards all the time because he said he wanted to raise reptiles, but I don't know if he's raising them now.

Korean: 파충류 같은 친구들은 온도도 조절해야 하고 굉장히 키우기 힘들 것 같아요.
English: Reptiles need temperature control and seem like they would be very difficult to raise.

Korean: 맞아요. 벌레나 파충류 키우는 사람들이 엄청 신경 많이 쓰는 것 같더라고요. 가격도 비싸고
English: Yes, I think people who raise insects or reptiles are very careful. They are also expensive.

Korean: 네, 크기는 작은데 사슴벌레 같은 작은 곤충도 비싸더라고요.
English: Yes, they are small in size, but even small insects like stag beetles are expensive.
Have you ever tried raising chicks sold at school?
I haven't raised one, but have you tried raising one?

Korean: 저 어릴 때 그거 사서 닭까지 키웠었어요.
English: I bought that when I was little and even raised chickens.

Korean: 정말요? 그거 다들 집에서 키우면 조금 있다가 죽어버리더라고요.
English: Really? If you raise them at home, they die after a while.

Korean: 저는 그냥 갖고 놀기만 했는데 저희 아버지가 열심히 키워서 결국 성공했네요.
English: I was just playing around with it, but my father worked hard to raise me, and I eventually succeeded.

Korean: 대단하시네요. 학교 앞에서 파는 병아리들은 건강도 원래 좋지 않다고 하던데 신기해요.
English: That's amazing. I heard that the chicks sold in front of schools aren't in good health to begin with. That's amazing.
Do you like traveling or camping?
Do you like traveling, even though you don't really like it?

Korean: 저도 번거로워서 그렇게 많이 좋아하는 편은 아닌데 막상 가면 재밌더라고요.
English: I don't like it that much because it's a hassle, but it's actually fun when you go.
Do you like the sea or the mountains?

Korean: 저는 바다가 좋아요. 정작 물놀이는 싫어하지만 바다는 보기만 해도 시원해져요.
English: I like the ocean. I don't really like playing in the water, but just looking at the ocean makes me feel refreshed.
Doesn't it feel refreshing just to look at the mountain?
Green leaves and wide view

Korean: 오르고 내려올 때 너무 힘들어서 좋아하지 않아요,
English: I don't like it because it's too hard to go up and down.
I guess you like mountains more?

Korean: 아니요. 저도 산보다 바다가 더 좋아요.
English: No. I like the sea better than the mountains.

Korean: 작년 여름에 빠지 놀러 갔었는데 확실히 물에서 노는 게 재밌더라고요.
English: I went to play in the water last summer and it was definitely fun to play in the water.

Korean: 저는 물에서 노는 건 싫어해요, 수영도 할 줄 모르고 좀 무섭더라고요.
English: I hate playing in the water, I can't swim and I'm a little scared.
I can't go in without a life jacket either.

Korean: 예전에 친구들이랑 캐리비안베이 갔다가 친구가 빠뜨려서 죽을 뻔했어요.
English: I went to Caribbean Bay with my friends a while ago, and my friend almost died because he dropped it.
Then it would be really scary,

Korean: 저는 발이 안 닿는 곳에는 절대 안 들어가요.
English: I never go where my feet can't reach.

Korean: 친구들이 다 수영할 줄 알아서 놀러 가면 저만 힘들어요.
English: When my friends all know how to swim and we go out to play, I find it hard.

Korean: 저는 기회 되면 패러글라이딩 해보고 싶어요.
English: I would like to try paragliding if I get the chance.
Paragliding looks fun too,
I want to learn fishing.

Korean: 저희 아버지가 낚시 가끔 데려가셔서 몇 번 해봤는데 저는 무슨 재미로 하는지 모르겠어요.
English: My father sometimes takes me fishing, so I've tried it a few times, but I don't know what's fun in it.

Korean: 저도 어렸을 때 아버지 따라서 많이 갔는데 고기만 잘 잡힌다면 재미있는 거 같아요.
English: I also went there a lot with my father when I was young, and I think it's fun as long as you catch a lot of fish.

Korean: 보트 타고 바다 한가운데 나가서도 해 봤는데 좀 무섭기도 하고 일단 물고기가 싫어서 별로 만지고 싶지도 않더라고요.
English: I tried going out to the middle of the ocean on a boat, but it was a bit scary and I don't like fish, so I didn't really want to touch them.

Korean: 저는 물고기는 잡을 수 있는데 지렁이 같은 거는 못 끼겠더라고요
English: I can catch fish, but I can't catch things like earthworms.

Korean: 살면서 제일 재밌게 했거나 제일 오래한 게임이 뭐예요?
English: What is the most fun or longest-played game you've ever played?

Korean: 저는 롤을 제일 오래했는데 지인들이랑 하면 재미있더라고요.
English: I've been playing LoL for the longest time, and it's fun to play with friends.
Weren't you a Roll Gold fan?
How long have you been doing this?

Korean: 처음 시작은 중학교 때였던 거 같은데 10년 해서 골드면 재능이 없는 거겠죠?
English: I think it started when I was in middle school, but if I've been gold for 10 years, then I guess I have no talent?

Korean: 재능 없으면 어때요. 그냥 재밌게 하면 됐죠.
English: So what if you don't have talent? Just have fun.
Do you know the game called Monster Hunter?

Korean: 제 친구가 했었는데 재미있다고 하더라고요. 되게 고사양 게임 아니에요?
English: My friend played it and said it was fun. Isn't it a really high-spec game?

Korean: 시리즈가 많은데 피시로 나온 건 사양 좀 있는 편이에요. 전 그 게임을 10년 넘게 했네요.
English: There are many series, but the ones that came out for PC have higher specs. I've been playing that game for over 10 years.

Korean: 되게 골수팬이시네요, 그만큼 매력이 있는 거겠죠?
English: You're such a die-hard fan, I guess that must be why you're so charming?

Korean: 솔직히 아직까지도 그만한 게임 못 본 것 같아요.
English: Honestly, I don't think I've ever seen a game quite like it.

Korean: 진입 장벽이 좀 높긴 한데 빠지면 인생 바쳐야 해요.
English: The barrier to entry is a bit high, but if you get into it, you'll have to dedicate your life to it.

Korean: 인생을 갈아 넣는 게 마치 문명 같은 게임이네요.
English: It's like a game of civilization where you have to change your life.
Have you tried a lot of civilization?
I played that game once

Korean: 전 한 판도 안 해봤는데 게임하다가 정신 차려 보면 몇 년씩 지나있다던데요.
English: I haven't played a single round, but they say that when you play a game and come to your senses, years have passed.

Korean: 한 판밖에 안 해서 그건 잘 모르겠는데 일단 한 판 끝나니까 해 떴어요.
English: I'm not sure because I only played one round, but once I finished one round, I felt refreshed.

Korean: 저는 한 판씩 하는 게임을 주로 해서 체력이 먼저 떨어지더라고요.
English: I mostly play games where I play one round at a time, so my stamina goes down first.

Korean: 나이 먹으니까 게임하는 데도 체력 많이 필요하더라고요. 옛날처럼 못할 거 같아요 이젠
English: As I get older, I need a lot of stamina to play games. I don't think I can do it like I used to.

Korean: 맞아요 저도 학생 때는 12시간씩도 앉아있었는데 힘들더라고요.
English: That's right. When I was a student, I used to sit for 12 hours at a time and it was hard.

Korean: 해외 여행 가 보신 적 있으세요?
English: Have you ever traveled abroad?

Korean: 해외 여행 가 본 적 없어요. 언제쯤 갈 수 있을까요?
English: I've never been abroad before. When will I be able to go?

Korean: 제가 봤을 땐 못 갈 거 같아요. 국내는 많이 다녀 보셨나요.
English: When I saw it, I didn't think I could go. Have you been to many places in the country?

Korean: 국내도 많이 안 다녔어요, 어디 많이 다니셨나요?
English: You haven't been around the country much, where have you been a lot?

Korean: 저도 딱히 여행을 많이 다녀본 편은 아닌데 그나마 가평이랑 제주도 여러 번 가봤고 부산이랑 속초처럼 유명한 데만 가봤어요.
English: I haven't really traveled much, but I've been to Gapyeong and Jeju Island several times, and only been to famous places like Busan and Sokcho.

Korean: 예전에 부산에 갔었을 때 아쿠아리움을 갔었는데 되게 예쁘더라고요.
English: When I went to Busan before, I went to the aquarium and it was really pretty.
I also want to go to the Busan Aquarium.

Korean: 서울에서는 몇 번 가봤는데 다른 지역도 궁금해요.
English: I've been to Seoul a few times, but I'm curious about other areas.

Korean: 가평으로 여행이나 휴가 많이 가시던데 괜찮은가요?
English: I heard that many people go to Gapyeong for travel or vacation. Is that okay?

Korean: 그냥 뻔해요. 남이섬이나 빠지 같은 거 다들 가는 곳 가는 거죠.
English: It's just obvious. You go to places that everyone else goes to, like Namiseom or Ppaji.
Jeju Island was okay though.
When you go to Jeju Island, the only thing you hear is Chinese.

Korean: 중국어는 안산에서 더 많이 들려서 익숙한 거 같아요. 저희 아랫집에서 중국인 살아요.
English: I think I'm more familiar with Chinese because I hear it more in Ansan. There's a Chinese person living downstairs from us.

Korean: 저희 집 근처도 중국어 써져 있는 식당도 많던데 요즘에는 국내에 중국인들이 많은 거 같아요.
English: There are a lot of restaurants near my house that have Chinese signs. I think there are a lot of Chinese people in Korea these days.

Korean: 저는 고등학생 때 수학여행으로 북한 놀러 갔던 게 기억에 남네요.
English: I remember going to North Korea on a school trip when I was a high school student.
That's amazing. Have you been to Geumgangsan?

Korean: 네. 금강산 갔다가 단체로 나방한테 피부병 걸려서 휴교했었어요. 지금도 구글에 치면 기사 떠요.
English: Yes. We went to Mt. Geumgang and got skin disease from moths in a group and had to take a leave of absence. Even now, if you search it on Google, you can find articles about it.

Korean: 도대체 금강산에는 어떤 나방들이 사는 걸까요?
English: What kind of moths live in Geumgangsan?
I wish fall would come quickly.
Yes, it's so hot these days.

Korean: 뭔가 갈수록 계절이 이상해져서 오히려 여름이 빨리 끝날 수도 있을 거 같아요.
English: The seasons are becoming more and more strange, so I feel like summer might end sooner.

Korean: 그랬으면 좋겠어요. 여름은 비도 많이 오고 너무 싫어요.
English: I wish it were so. I hate summer because it rains a lot.

Korean: 근데 제가 또 추위를 많이 타서 겨울도 힘들어서 빨리 계약이나 끝났으면 좋겠어요.
English: But I also catch cold easily and have a hard time in winter, so I hope my contract ends quickly.

Korean: 저도 추위를 많이 타긴 하지만 요즘 날씨는 정말 이상해요.
English: I feel cold a lot too, but the weather has been really strange lately.

Korean: 이번 주 내내 비 온다 그래 놓고 또 안 오네요.
English: It was supposed to rain all week, but it hasn't rained again.

Korean: 겨울 되면 또 눈 엄청 올까 봐 걱정이에요.
English: I'm worried that it'll snow a lot again in winter.

Korean: 눈도 예전에는 좋았는데 교통사고만 나고 땅도 더러워지고 역시 가을이 최고예요.
English: The snow used to be nice, but now there are traffic accidents and the ground is dirty. Fall is the best.

Korean: 맞아요. 근데 한 이주 삼주 있으면 끝나잖아요.
English: That's right. But it'll be over in a week or three weeks.

Korean: 가을 옷 다 입어보지도 못하고 끝나는 거 같아요.
English: I feel like it's ending without me even getting to try on all the fall clothes.

Korean: 맞아요 날씨가 점점 여름하고 겨울만 남는 것 같아요.
English: That's right, it seems like the weather is gradually becoming more like summer and winter.

Korean: 제발 내년 여름에는 마스크라도 안 썼으면 좋겠네요.
English: I really hope we don't have to wear masks next summer.

Korean: 여름에 마스크 쓰는 게 너무 괴로워요.
English: It's so annoying to wear a mask in the summer.

Korean: 저희 시험 볼 때쯤 계절이 괜찮은 거 같아요.
English: I think the season will be nice around the time we take our exams.

Korean: 그래서 일부러 그때 시험을 보는 거 아닐까요?
English: So maybe you took the test at that time on purpose?
You're smart. Are you currently attending Seoul National University?
I always pass by on the subway.

Korean: ** 선수 메달 반납 논란이 결국 다 거짓말이었대요.
English: ** The controversy over the athletes returning their medals turned out to be a lie.

Korean: 네, 저도 봤어요. 사회적 갈등 조장하는 집단들 왜 그러는지 모르겠네요.
English: Yes, I've seen it too. I don't understand why groups that promote social conflict do that.

Korean: 트위터에 선동하는 사람들도 문제지만 그걸 그냥 그대로 기사화시키고 보도하는 기자들도 문제가 많아요.
English: People who instigate on Twitter are a problem, but the reporters who simply write articles and report on them are also problematic.

Korean: 맞아요, 일단 트위터는 믿고 거른다는 생각인데 아님 말고 식으로 퍼다 나르더라고요.
English: Yes, I thought I could trust Twitter and filter it out, but if not, they spread it around like crazy.

Korean: 예전에 **가 ** 디스곡 썼다가 엄청 까였을 때랑 비슷한 거 같아요. 허위 선동 날조 성향이
English: I think it's similar to when ** wrote a diss song and got criticized a lot. There's a tendency to fabricate false instigation.

Korean: 기본적인 사실 확인도 안 하고 우르르 몰려가서 소리 지르고 보는 사람들이 너무 많아요.
English: There are too many people who just rush in and yell without even checking the basic facts.

Korean: **도 이번에 무슨 ** 옹호하는 글 썼다가 비공개 계정으로 돌렸더라고요.
English: **This time, I wrote an article defending ** and then changed it to a private account.

Korean: 그 사람도 단순히 ** 선수 공격하는 사람들이 있다는 말만 듣고 썼다가 그렇게 된 거죠,
English: That guy just wrote after hearing that there were people who attacked ** players, and that's how it turned out.

Korean: 오히려 연세 좀 있으신 분들이 젊은 사람들보다 가짜 뉴스에 혹하시더라고요.
English: Rather, older people are more susceptible to fake news than younger people.

Korean: 맞아요. 근데 그만큼 파급력이 크고 워낙 민감한 시기라 몰랐다는 말로는 못 넘어가니까 스스로 좀 알아보고 썼으면 좋겠어요.
English: That's right. But since the impact is so big and it's such a sensitive time, you can't just say you didn't know, so I hope you do some research yourself and write about it.

Korean: 외신 기자도 관련 내용 기사로 썼다고 했는데 알고 보니까 그것도 본인들이 직접 제보했던 거더라고요.
English: They said that foreign correspondents also wrote articles about the related content, but it turned out that they had also reported it themselves.

Korean: 이상하게 그쪽 관련 주제에 대해서는 다들 한마음 한뜻으로 그쪽 편 드는 것 같아요.
English: Strangely enough, it seems like everyone is on your side when it comes to that topic.
**I haven't been able to return to broadcasting yet

Korean: 근데 실제로는 그런 사람들 잘 못 봤어요,
English: But in reality, I haven't seen many people like that.

Korean: 당장 제 여자친구나 여동생도 전혀 관련 없고 오히려 싫어하는데 인터넷에서만 말 많은 거 같아요.
English: Right now, my girlfriend and sister have nothing to do with it and actually hate it, but it seems like there's a lot of talk about it on the internet.

Korean: 저도 제 주변에서는 본 적 없는데 제 친구네 여동생이 그거였어요.
English: I've never seen it around me, but my friend's younger sister had it.

Korean: 사상은 자유지만 논리적인 부분이 하나도 없는데 어쩌다 그런 생각을 가지게 되는지 모르겠네요.
English: Thought is free, but there is no logic to it at all, so I don't know how people come to have such thoughts.

Korean: 그냥 편하게는 살고 싶고 생각은 별로 없고 그러다 보니까 그렇게 된 거 같아요.
English: I just wanted to live comfortably and not think much, so I think that's how it turned out.

Korean: 논리적으로 자기 주장 펼치는 사람들을 정말 한 번도 못 봐서 이제는 관련 주제만으로도 피로감이 느껴져요.
English: I've never seen anyone argue logically, so now I feel tired just thinking about the topic.

Korean: 최근에 전 세계적으로 이상 기후 현상 때문에 다들 난리더라고요.
English: Recently, people all over the world are in chaos because of the abnormal weather phenomenon.
In Canada and the US, even slippers melt?

Korean: 네 맞아요. 미국에 이번에 50도 넘어서 해변가에 조개들이 전부 다 익어서 벌어졌대요.
English: Yes, that's right. In the US, it recently got over 50 degrees and all the clams on the beach were cooked and opened up.

Korean: 타이어도 녹고 북극의 눈물이 아니라 이제는 북극의 오열이겠어요.
English: The tires are melting and now it's not Arctic tears, it's Arctic sobs.

Korean: 오열할 북극이 이제 없어질 거 같아요.
English: It seems like the North Pole that we have to cry over will no longer exist.

Korean: 중국에 홍수 나서 몇백 명 죽었다고 하더라고요.
English: They say that hundreds of people died in floods in China.

Korean: 매해마다 기록 갱신하는데 앞으로 얼마나 더 더워질지 모르겠네요.
English: Every year we break records, and I don't know how much hotter it will get in the future.

Korean: 그러게요. 지구도 얼마 안 남은 거 같아요.
English: Yeah, I think the Earth doesn't have much time left.

Korean: 엘론 머스크 화성 갈 때 같이 따라 갈까요?
English: Would you like to go with Elon Musk to Mars?

Korean: 저희가 탈 자리가 있으면 좋겠지만 껴줄까요?
English: I'd like to have a seat for us, but would you mind giving us a seat?

Korean: 지금부터 꾸준히 테슬라에 투자하면 언젠가 알아보고 데려가 주지 않을까요?
English: If I invest steadily in Tesla from now on, won't they recognize me and take me there someday?
I wish it were so,

Korean: 지구는 앞으로 얼마나 더 살 수 있을까요?
English: How much longer can the Earth survive?

Korean: 저희가 마지막일 수도 있을 거 같아요.
English: I think we might be the last.

Korean: 이번에 겨울까지 코로나 확산 이어지면 또 새로운 변이 생길 수 있다고 하더라고요.
English: They say that if the spread of coronavirus continues until this winter, new mutations may appear.

Korean: 지금 변이도 해결 못 하는데 또 얼마나 더 괴롭힐까요?
English: How much longer will they torment us when we can't even solve the mutation now?

Korean: 당장 태풍도 생겨서 오고 있다고 하네요.
English: They say a typhoon is coming right now.

Korean: 좀 평화롭게 살고 싶은데 쉽지 않아요.
English: I want to live a little more peacefully, but it's not easy.
I wish you would avoid our country.

Korean: 그래도 다행히 폭염은 이번 주가 마지막이고 점점 내려갈 것 같다고 하네요.
English: Fortunately, the heat wave is expected to end this week and gradually subside.
That's really great news.
I wish fall would come soon.

Korean: 저 아는 동생이 최근에 전신 지방 흡입을 했어요. 효과가 좋은 거 같나요?
English: A friend of mine recently had full body liposuction. Do you think it was effective?

Korean: 엄청 좋죠. 돈도 몇 백씩 들고 지방도 엄청 많이 뽑았던데 신기하더라고요. 하루 만에 날씬해졌어요.
English: It's amazing. I spent hundreds of dollars and had a lot of fat removed, but it was amazing. I became slim in just one day.

Korean: 저 아는 동생이 최근에 전신 지방 흡입을 했어요. 효과가 좋은 거 같나요?
English: A friend of mine recently had full body liposuction. Do you think it was effective?

Korean: 운동을 하지 않아도 살을 뺄 수 있다니 세상이 참 좋네요.
English: It's a wonderful world where you can lose weight without exercising.

Korean: 네. 흡입한 곳에 피멍 들고 계속 압박 붕대로 감싸고 있더라고요. 회복될 때까지
English: Yes. There was a bruise on the area where it was sucked and it was wrapped with a pressure bandage until it recovered.
I think it would be very painful,

Korean: 저는 코로나 끝나면 피부에 생긴 흉 좀 지우고 싶어요.
English: When the coronavirus is over, I want to erase some of the scars on my skin.

Korean: 피부 어디에 흉이 지셨는데요? 칼싸움이라도 하셨나요?
English: Where on your skin are you scarred? Have you been in a sword fight?

Korean: 마스크 때문에 여드름이 났었는데 되게 심했어서 점이 된 친구들도 많더라고요.
English: Many of my friends had acne because of the mask, and it was so bad that it turned into freckles.

Korean: 지금은 거의 한 6개월 동안 약 먹어서 괜찮아졌지만요.
English: I've been taking medication for almost six months now and I'm feeling better.

Korean: 요즘엔 코로나 때문에 피부과 가기도 힘드시겠네요.
English: These days, it must be difficult to go to the dermatologist because of the coronavirus.
Are there any medications you can take for acne?

Korean: 네, 이미 진 흉은 어쩔 수 없는데 더 이상 안 나게 해야 해서 꾸준히 먹었더니 마스크 써도 이제는 새로 안 나더라고요.
English: Yes, I already had a scar, but I had to keep taking it to prevent any more, and now even when I wear a mask, no new ones appear.

Korean: 오 신기하네요. 제 동생도 여드름 때문에 고민인데 추천해 줘야겠네요.
English: Oh, that's amazing. My sister also has acne problems, so I'll have to recommend it.
Are you going to a dermatologist and getting it made?

Korean: 네, 처음에는 하루에 한 알씩 먹다가 좀 지나면 이틀에 한 알 더 지나면 일주일에 두 알씩 그렇게 먹으라고 하더라고요.
English: Yes, at first, they told me to take one pill a day, then one pill every two days, and then two pills a week.

Korean: 저는 여드름은 안 나는데 탈모약 지어 먹고 있어요.
English: I don't get acne, but I'm taking hair loss medication.
Are you here for a visit or for preventive measures?

Korean: 예방으로요. 지금은 아직 안 빠지는데 아버지가 탈모면 빠질 확률 높다고 미리 먹는 게 좋다 그래서 먹고 있어요.
English: As a preventive measure. It hasn't fallen out yet, but my father said that if you lose hair, there's a high chance of it falling out, so it's better to take it in advance, so I'm taking it.

Korean: 저도 먹어야 할 텐데 말이에요. 탈모는 예방이 최고라고 했어요.
English: I guess I should eat it too. They say that prevention is the best way to treat hair loss.

Korean: 삼십대 되니까 주변 친구들이 자꾸 뱃살이 나와서 저도 불안하네요.
English: Now that I'm in my thirties, I'm starting to feel anxious because my friends around me keep getting belly fat.

Korean: 그래도 삼십대로 안 보이세요, 관리를 잘 한 덕인가요?
English: Still, you don't look like you're in your thirties. Is it because you take good care of yourself?

Korean: 꾸준히 운동을 하고 있기는 한데 술을 좋아해서 더 빡세게 관리를 해야 될 거 같아요.
English: I've been exercising regularly, but I like to drink, so I think I need to manage it more strictly.

Korean: 그러네요, 저는 술은 잘 안 해서 운동만 하면 되는데 너무 좋아하는 운동은 풋살밖에 없어요.
English: That's right, I don't drink much so I just need to exercise, but the only sport I really like is futsal.

Korean: 요즘에는 코로나 때문에 헬스장도 못 가니까 그냥 집에서 홈트하는 게 최고인 거 같아요. 시간도 많으시잖아요.
English: These days, because of the coronavirus, I can't even go to the gym, so I think it's best to just do home workouts. You have a lot of time.

Korean: 그러게요, 허리가 안 좋아서 더 해야 된다고 생각은 하는데 막상 하려니까 귀찮더라고요.
English: Yeah, I think I should do more because my back is not good, but when it comes to actually doing it, I feel lazy.

Korean: 살면서 뭐 수술 같은 거 해본 적 있으세요?
English: Have you ever had any kind of surgery in your life?

Korean: 저는 수술은 한 번도 없는데 수술하신 적 있으세요?
English: I've never had surgery, but have you ever had surgery?

Korean: 포경수술 빼고는 어릴 때 머리를 다쳐서 수술 한번 한 적 있어요.
English: Aside from circumcision, I've only had one surgery when I was young due to a head injury.
Do you have insurance now?

Korean: 네. 몇 개 들고 있긴 한데 그냥 건강했으면 좋겠네요.
English: Yeah, I have a few, but I just want them to be healthy.

Korean: 주변에 코로나 걸렸다가 완치된 친구가 둘 있는데 둘 다 후유증이 있대요.
English: I have two friends who recovered from COVID-19, and they both have aftereffects.

Korean: 인터넷에서 보니까 냄새도 잘 못 맡게 된다고 하더라고요.
English: I saw on the internet that it also makes it hard to smell.

Korean: 네. 한 명은 5월에 완치됐는데 실제로 냄새 잘 못 맡아서 음식 맛도 예전처럼 안 느껴진다고 하더라고요.
English: Yes. One person was cured in May, but he said that he actually couldn't smell well and that he couldn't taste food like he used to.

Korean: 무섭네요, 마스크 꼭 잘 쓰고 손도 잘 씻어야겠어요.
English: It's scary. I have to wear a mask and wash my hands well.

Korean: 네. 제일 무서운 건 나머지 한 명은 탈모가 왔대요.
English: Yes. The scariest thing is that the other one is losing his hair.

Korean: 정말 무섭네요, 탈모 예방약을 먹었어도 탈모가 왔을까요?
English: It's really scary. Even if I took hair loss prevention medication, would I still have hair loss?

Korean: 이번 주에 인터넷 쇼핑몰에서 바지를 샀는데 요즘 도메스틱 브랜드 가격이 너무 비싸네요.
English: I bought some pants from an online shopping mall this week, but domestic brands are so expensive these days.

Korean: 특히 여자 옷보다 남자 옷이 더 비싼 경향이 있어요.
English: Men's clothing in particular tends to be more expensive than women's clothing.

Korean: 네 맞아요. 여자 옷은 애초에 보세 위주라 별로 비싸진 않은데 남자 옷은 유명 브랜드 아니더라도 요즘  반팔티만 해도 3~4만 원은 하더라고요.
English: Yes, that's right. Women's clothes are mostly duty-free, so they're not that expensive, but men's clothes, even if they're not famous brands, cost 30,000 to 40,000 won these days for just a short-sleeved T-shirt.

Korean: 맞아요, 원단이 들어가면 얼마나 더 들어간다고 그렇게 차이가 나나 모르겠어요.
English: Yeah, I don't know how much more fabric would make that much of a difference.

Korean: 이번에 배달의 민족 B마트로 장 봤는데 되게 좋더라고요.
English: I recently went grocery shopping at Baedal Minjok B Mart and it was really good.

Korean: 제 친구가 거기서 일했었는데 생각보다 많은 사람들이 이용하더라고요.
English: My friend worked there and there were more people there than I thought.

Korean: 거기 그냥 대형 마트랑 똑같이 생긴 건가요?
English: Is that place just like any other big box store?

Korean: 그렇다고 하는데 이제 배달 음식점처럼 주문이 들어오면 맞춰서 담는다고 하더라고요.
English: That's what they say, but they say that now they're like a delivery restaurant, they pack the food as orders come in.

Korean: 네. 원래 롯데마트 같은 곳에서 샀었는데 이번에 처음 배민에서 사보니까 그냥 음식 배달처럼 바로 출발하더라고요.
English: Yes. I used to buy it from places like Lotte Mart, but this time I bought it from Baemin for the first time and it was shipped right away, just like food delivery.

Korean: 제가 편의점 알바했을 때도 그런 서비스가 있었는데 그거만 전문적으로 하면 더 효율적일 거 같아요.
English: There was a similar service when I worked at a convenience store, but I think it would be more efficient if we specialized in that.
Convenience stores have also improved a lot.

Korean: 제가 편의점 알바할 때는 그런 거 없었거든요. 그냥 호빵이나 돌려서 팔고 그랬는데
English: When I worked at a convenience store, there was no such thing. I just sold steamed buns and stuff.

Korean: 야간에 야식으로 편의점에서 시켜서 드시는 분들이 있더라고요.
English: There are people who order food from convenience stores at night as a late-night snack.

Korean: 그런 건 배달 대행 불러서 보내나요?
English: Do you send that by calling a delivery service?

Korean: 네, 다 담아서 호출하면 음식점처럼 기사님이 오시는데 배민 마트는 모르겠네요.
English: Yes, if you put everything in the cart and call, a delivery person will come just like at a restaurant, but I don't know about Baemin Mart.

Korean: 신기하네요. 아무튼 요즘은 전자상거래가 주가 된 거 같아요.
English: It's amazing. Anyway, it seems like e-commerce is the main thing these days.

Korean: 네, 맞아요 앞으로는 거래량이 더 늘지 않을까 싶네요.
English: Yes, that's right. I think the trading volume will increase even more in the future.
Do you have a favorite idol or singer these days?

Korean: 저는 아이돌이나 가수에 관심이 없어서 모르는데 좋아하는 가수가 있으신가요?
English: I don't know because I'm not interested in idols or singers, but do you have a favorite singer?

Korean: 사실 요즘 티비도 잘 안보고 원래 아이돌은 별로 안 보는데 카리나가 이쁘더라고요.
English: Actually, I don't watch TV much these days and I don't really watch idols, but Karina is pretty.
Which girl group is Karina a member of?

Korean: 네. 에스파라는 걸그룹인데 한번 꼭 찾아보셨으면 좋겠네요.
English: Yes. It's a girl group called Espa. I hope you check them out.
My favorite celebrity is Lee Som.
Who is Lee Som? Is she an actress?

Korean: 모델 출신 배우인데 영화나 드라마에 가끔 나와요.
English: She is a model-turned-actress who occasionally appears in movies and dramas.
I guess I'll have to look it up sometime when I'm bored.
Do you have a favorite comedian?
I find Kim Yong-myeong so funny.

Korean: 저 개그 프로는 잘 안 보는데 이용진이 하는 괴릴라 데이트 아시나요? 그거 재밌던데
English: I don't really watch gag shows, but do you know about the gorilla date that Lee Yong-jin does? That was funny.
Isn't that finished?
It was one of my favorite shows.

Korean: 몰라요. 챙겨본 건 아니고 그냥 좋아하는 래퍼 나올 때 몇 개 봤는데 진짜 웃기더라고요.
English: I don't know. I didn't watch it, I just watched a few when my favorite rappers came out and they were really funny.

Korean: 저는 거의 다 챙겨봤는데 이제 더 안 하는 거 같더라고요.
English: I've tried almost all of them, but I don't think I'll do them anymore.

Korean: 아쉽네요. 유튜브에 좋좋소라는 웹드라마 있는데 그거 추천드릴게요. 정주행 보장합니다.
English: That's too bad. There's a web drama called "Jojoso" on YouTube. I recommend it. It's guaranteed to be a hit.

Korean: 아 그거 유명해서 보려다 말았는데 진짜 중소기업 잘 담아냈다고 하더라고요.
English: Oh, I was going to watch it because it's famous, but I heard it's really good at capturing small and medium-sized businesses.

Korean: 제일 최근에 본 영화가 어떤 거예요?
English: What is the last movie you saw?

Korean: 본 지 너무 오래 돼서 기억이 잘 안 나는데 다만 악에서 구하소서 같아요.
English: It's been so long since I've seen it that I don't remember it well, but it's like Deliver Us from Evil.
It's really been a long time.

Korean: 저는 최근에 크루엘라랑 블랙위도우 보고 왔는데 아시나요?
English: I recently saw Cruella and Black Widow, you know?

Korean: 크루엘라는 머리 색깔 반반인 캐릭터인 거만 알아요.
English: All I know is that Cruella is a character with half-and-half hair color.
I didn't even know Black Widow was released.

Korean: 크루엘라가 그 101마리 달마시안에 나오는 빌런 캐릭터 가지고 리메이크한 건데 그냥 조커처럼 외전인 것 같더라고요.
English: Cruella is a remake of the villain character from 101 Dalmatians, but it seems like a spin-off like Joker.

Korean: 되게 캐릭터가 독특한 거 같은데 저도 반반 머리로 염색해보고 싶어요.
English: The character seems very unique. I also want to try dyeing my hair half and half.
What color do you want to dye your hair?
I really hope to see you at work sometime

Korean: 저는 갈색 계열밖에 안 해봤는데 탈색해서 회색도 한번 해보고 싶어요.
English: I've only tried brown tones, but I'd like to bleach my hair and try gray.

Korean: 아 저도 탈색해서 코토리베이지 같은 색 해보고 싶었는데 역시 탈색은 겁나더라고요.
English: Ah, I also wanted to bleach my hair and try a color like Kotori Beige, but bleaching is scary.

Korean: 저도 하려고 했었는데 그때 피부가 안 좋았어서 원장님이 극구 반대하시더라고요.
English: I was going to do it too, but my skin wasn't good at the time, so the director was strongly against it.

Korean: 그건 그렇고 블랙 위도우는 어벤저스랑 이어지는 내용이 많아서 약간 팬들 보라고 만든 느낌이었어요.
English: By the way, Black Widow has a lot of content that connects to the Avengers, so it feels like it was made a bit for the fans.

Korean: 장르가 장르이다 보니 팬층이 두터워서 그렇게 만들면 좋지 않나요?
English: Since the genre is what it is, it has a large fan base, so wouldn't it be good to make it like that?

Korean: 팬들은 어차피 보니까 팬 아닌 사람도 쉽게 볼 수 있게 만드는 게 좋은 거 같아요.
English: Since fans will watch it anyway, I think it's better to make it so that non-fans can watch it easily too.

Korean: 여자친구는 별로 재밌게 보진 않은 거 같더라고요.
English: My girlfriend didn't seem to find it very amusing.

Korean: 저같이 잘 모르는 사람은 그렇게 나왔다고 하면 안 볼 거 같긴 해요.
English: People like me who don't know much about it probably won't watch it if you tell them to do so.

Korean: 그래도 마블은 마블이라 잘 만들긴 했어요. 이쁘더라구요.
English: But Marvel is Marvel, so they did a good job. It was pretty.

Korean: 마블 확실히 팬층이 두터운 거 같아요.
English: Marvel definitely seems to have a large fan base.
What did you eat last night?

Korean: 저는 어제 저녁에 국밥 먹었어요. ** 씨는요?
English: I ate noodles last night. What about **?

Korean: 저는 어제 집에 있던 고기 구워 먹었어요.
English: I ate grilled meat that I had at home yesterday.

Korean: 와 진짜요? 삼겹살? 아니면 다른 부위 드셨어요? 하하
English: Wow, really? Pork belly? Or did you eat another part? Haha

Korean: 냉동실에 소고기가 오래 있었어서 먹지 않으면 안 될 거 같아서 먹었어요! 오래 둬서 별로 맛은 없었네요.
English: I had some beef in the freezer for a long time, so I ate it because I felt like I had to eat it! It didn't taste that good because it was kept for a long time.
Wow, but still beef! I'm jealous! Haha

Korean: 소고기 하니까 갑자기 육회 생각나는데 ** 씨 혹시 육회 좋아하세요? 저는 육회를 엄청 좋아해요.
English: Speaking of beef, I suddenly thought of raw beef. **, do you like raw beef by any chance? I really like raw beef.

Korean: 저도 육회 좋아하는데 양념이 빨간 육회 별로 안 좋아해요.
English: I like raw meat too, but I don't really like raw meat with red seasoning.

Korean: 지역마다 스타일이 좀 다른데 흔히 볼 수 있는 건 고추장 양념이더라고요.
English: The style varies from region to region, but the most common one is the gochujang seasoning.

Korean: 아! 그건 정말 똑같네요. 저도 양념이 묻혀진 육회는 별로 안 좋아해요.
English: Oh! That's exactly the same. I don't like seasoned raw meat either.

Korean: 그래서 뷔페 가면 양념 육회인지 아닌지부터 먼저 봐요. 하하
English: So when I go to a buffet, I first check if it's seasoned raw beef or not. Haha

Korean: ** 씨는 뷔페 가면 어떤 음식을 먼저 드세요?
English: ** When you go to a buffet, what food do you eat first?

Korean: 저는 요즘은 그냥 연어회 같은 거부터 샐러드 같은 거?
English: These days, I just eat things like salmon sashimi and salad?

Korean: 저도 육회만 예외적으로 먼저 먹고 회를 자주 먹게 되네요. 가면 갈수록 소화 기능이 떨어져서 하하
English: I also eat raw fish often after eating raw fish first as an exception. My digestive function deteriorates as I eat raw fish. Haha
** Do you have anything like this?

Korean: 저는 소화 기능이 떨어져도 먹고 싶은 건 먹어야 되기 때문에 그냥 먹고 아픈 쪽을 택해요...
English: I have to eat what I want even though my digestive function is poor, so I just eat and choose to be sick...

Korean: 저만 그런지는 모르겠지만 소화 안 될 때는 매실 엑기스가 약보다 효과가 더 좋더라고요. 하하
English: I don't know if it's just me, but when I have indigestion, plum extract works better than medicine. Haha

Korean: 저는 소화가 안 되는 상태를 뛰어넘고 바로 체하는 편이라서 매실로 해결이 안 되더라고요?
English: I tend to skip over indigestion and just vomit, so plums didn't solve the problem?

Korean: 아 정말요? 저는 심하게 체해도 매실로 해결이 되더라고요. 사람마다 다 다른가 봐요!
English: Oh really? Even when I have severe diarrhea, I can solve it with plums. I guess it's different for everyone!

Korean: 매실청은 그냥 좋아해서 자주 먹긴 해요! 갑자기 먹고 싶네요.
English: I like plum extract, so I eat it often! But I suddenly want to eat it.
What did you eat last night?

Korean: 매실청 좋죠! 여름에 커피나 다른 음료 대신에 타 마시면 건강에도 좋고 미용에도 좋을 거구요.
English: Plum extract is good! If you drink it instead of coffee or other drinks in the summer, it's good for your health and beauty.
I suddenly want to drink it too. Refreshing!

Korean: 이사하시고 집 정리는 이제 다 되셨겠죠?
English: You've moved in and finished tidying up the house, right?

Korean: 네 이제야 좀 정리가 마무리 됐네요. 그래도 아직까지 채워 넣을 게 많아요. 아직 식기 세트도 제대로 사지 못했네요.
English: Yes, I'm finally done with organizing. But I still have a lot to fill in. I haven't even bought a proper set of dishes yet.

Korean: ** 씨는 혹시 정수기 설득 되셨어요? 하하
English: ** Did you get the water purifier by any chance? Haha
No, my logic was weak, Kiki

Korean: 그냥 저는 얼음 정수기가 갖고 싶은데 마침 방탄소년단이 씨에프에 나오길래 그걸로 꼬셨더니 덕질이 소비로 이어지는 데에 한계가 있나 봐요.
English: I just wanted an ice water purifier, and BTS happened to be on CF, so I was tempted by that, but I guess there's a limit to how much fandom can lead to consumption.

Korean: 아무래도 정수기가 가격이 만만치는 않다 보니... 하하
English: After all, water purifiers are not cheap... haha
And then I bought a cell phone.

Korean: ** 씨는 혹시 더 사고 싶은 가구나 인테리어 소품 이런 것 없나요?
English: ** Are there any other furniture or interior items you would like to buy?

Korean: 침대 머리 맡에 놓을 협탁을 2년째 사지 못하고 있네요.
English: I haven't been able to buy a bedside table for two years.

Korean: 직접 가서 사고 싶은데 나가질 않아서 하하
English: I want to go and buy it myself but they don't go out haha

Korean: 아 저도 머리 맡에 놓을 협탁이 하나 있으면 편하겠다 생각을 했어요.
English: Oh, I was thinking that it would be convenient to have a nightstand to put by the bedside.

Korean: 저는 빨래 바구니를 사야 하는데 마땅한 게 없네요.
English: I need to buy a laundry basket, but I can't find anything suitable.

Korean: 빨리 사야 하는데 ** 씨는 아파트라서 베란다가 있죠?
English: I need to buy it quickly, but ** lives in an apartment, so there's a veranda, right?

Korean: 네. 저는 확장 안 된 아파트라서 베란다 있어요.
English: Yes, I have a balcony because my apartment is not an extension.
I chose that place because of the veranda...

Korean: 좋겠어요. 저도 베란다가 있으면 빨래 걱정 안 해도 되는데 원룸이다 보니까 아무래도 빨래 건조 걱정이 되더라고요.
English: That would be nice. If I had a veranda, I wouldn't have to worry about laundry, but since it's a studio apartment, I'm worried about drying the laundry.

Korean: 미니 건조기를 사야 하나 심하게 고민 중이에요.
English: I'm seriously considering buying a mini dryer.

Korean: 제습기를 빨래 널 동안 돌리는 사람도 있더라고요.
English: Some people even run a dehumidifier while hanging their laundry.

Korean: 네 그렇게 하려고 하는데 그래도 냄새가 나서 어떻게 해야 좋을지 고민이에요.
English: Yes, I'm trying to do that, but it still smells, so I'm not sure what to do.
Do you know of any way to do this?

Korean: 아무래도 실내 건조용 세제를 쓰는 게 조금이나마 낫긴 해요!
English: I think it's a little better to use an indoor drying detergent!
Oh, Downey has a detergent like that.
Have you ever tried it?

Korean: 저 그거 나올 때부터 꾸준히 썼는데 처음엔 차이를 모르겠다가 안 쓰니까 티가 나더라고요...
English: I've been using it consistently since it came out, and at first I couldn't tell the difference, but when I stopped using it, it became noticeable...

Korean: 근데 실내에서 말리면 어쩔 수가 없어요.
English: But there's nothing you can do if you dry it indoors.
Oh, then I definitely have to try it too.

Korean: 진짜 효과가 있다면 안 쓸 이유가 없네요.
English: If it really works, there's no reason not to use it.

Korean: 진짜 빨래 냄새 때문에 스트레스 받더라고요.
English: I was really stressed out because of the smell of laundry.

Korean: 아니면 급할 때 코인워시 같은 데 가셔서 건조하는 방법도 괜찮지 않을까요!
English: Or, if you're in a hurry, wouldn't it be a good idea to go to a coin wash and have it dried?

Korean: 안 그래도 그 방법도 생각해 봤네요. 하하
English: I thought about that method too. Haha
It would be convenient if there was a coin laundry shop.

Korean: 베란다에서 빨래 건조할 때 혹시 천장형으로 건조대 쓰세요 아니면 그냥 일반 빨래 건조대 쓰세요?
English: When drying laundry on the veranda, do you use a ceiling-mounted drying rack or just a regular drying rack?

Korean: 요즘 지하철을 7시 16분에 타면 마주치는 사람이 있는데 그 사람 너무 민폐 끼치고 뻔뻔해서 스트레스예요.
English: These days, when I take the subway at 7:16, I run into someone who is so annoying and shameless that it stresses me out.

Korean: 그래서 또 시간 앞당겨서 13분 차를 타려고 알람을 또 5분 당겼어요.
English: So I set my alarm back 5 minutes to catch the 13-minute train.

Korean: 어떤 사람인데요? 갑자기 급 궁금해지네요. 하하
English: What kind of person is he? I suddenly became curious. Haha.

Korean: 지하철에 앉을 자리는 없고 보통 서는데 그 사람이 저보다 좀 나중에 타거든요.
English: There are no seats on the subway, so people usually stand, but that person gets on a little after me.

Korean: 근데 꼭 제가 서 있는 특정 자리를 본인도 고집하는지 거기에 비집고 들어와요.
English: But he insists on the specific spot I'm standing in and he comes in there and makes fun of me.

Korean: 그리고 쳐다보면 애써 시선 무시하고 지하철 흔들릴 때마다 꿋꿋이 자기 자리 잡음 키키
English: And when I look at her, she tries to ignore my gaze and firmly holds her place every time the subway shakes.

Korean: 음... 다들 자기가 서고 싶은 자리가 있어도 사람 있으면 다른 곳으로 가는데 그 사람 참 어떻게 보면 뻔뻔하네요.
English: Well... everyone has a spot they want to stand, but if there's someone there, they go somewhere else. That person is really shameless.

Korean: 저는 지하철 탈 때 항상 하는 생각이 사람들이 입구 말고 안쪽으로 좀 들어갔으면 좋겠어요...
English: When I ride the subway, I always think, I wish people would go inside instead of at the entrance...

Korean: 아 맞아요! 아니면 서 있다가도 문 열리면 좀 비켜주든지...
English: Oh, that's right! Or, if you're standing, step aside when the door opens...

Korean: 사람 많을 때는 내리고 다시 타도 될 건데 꼭 문 앞에 서서 핸드폰 끝까지 보고 있는 사람이 있어요. 무슨 폰 중독도 아니고...
English: When there are a lot of people, you can get off and get back on, but there's always someone standing in front of the door looking at their phone all the time. It's not like they're addicted to their phone or anything...

Korean: 그리고 오히려 내리는 사람들이 어쩔 수 없이 좀 닿는다고 자기가 성질내고 키키
English: And rather, the people who get off have no choice but to touch it and get angry

Korean: 그러니까요. 사람 많은 지하철에서는 어쩔 수 없는 건데 왜 그런 걸로 괜히 예민하게 구는지...
English: Well, it can't be helped on crowded subways, so why are you being so sensitive about that...

Korean: 그게 싫으면 자차를 이용하라고 얘기하고 싶어요.
English: If you don't like that, I'd like to tell you to use your own car.

Korean: 자차 이용... 아... 또 서울 시내 교통량 만만치 않죠...
English: By car... Ah... Also, the traffic in Seoul is no joke...

Korean: 제가 퇴근길에 친구랑 차 타고 가는데 6시 땡 하면 내려가잖아요?
English: I'm riding in the car with a friend on my way home from work, and we get off at exactly 6 o'clock, right?
When I get home, it's 7:30 at the earliest? Usually 40 minutes.

Korean: 헉... 그렇게 치면 차라리 지하철이 나을 수도 있겠네요.
English: Oh my... If you do it like that, the subway might be better.

Korean: 저는 빠르게 나가면 7시 조금 넘어서 도착하는 것 같아요!
English: If I leave quickly, I think I'll arrive a little after 7!

Korean: 아 근데 시간은 그래도 집에 가는 지하철은 너무 너무 사람이 많아서 그거 타면 너무 지쳐요.
English: Oh, but I still don't have time. The subway ride home is so crowded that I get really tired when I ride it.
Really terrible Kiki

Korean: 그건 그래요... 저도 역삼에서 진짜 한 방에 타 본 적이 없어요 키키
English: That's right... I've never actually been in a room in Yeoksam before Kiki

Korean: 저는 반대 방향으로 타는데 역삼역에서는 좀 괜찮아요.
English: I ride in the opposite direction and it's pretty good at Yeoksam Station.
But if you transfer to Line 7 at Konkuk University Station, then that's when it really starts...
I heard that Line 7 is really crowded.
Is there more than line 2?

Korean: 저는 여태 2호선 타고 사람 많다고 느껴 본 적이 왕십리에서 2호선 타고 강남 방향으로 올 때 정도 외에는 출근길이나 퇴근길엔 없는 것 같아요.
English: I don't think I've ever felt crowded on Line 2 except when I was going from Wangsimni to Gangnam on Line 2, and I don't think it's ever crowded on the way to or from work.

Korean: 진짜요? 저는 항상 사당에서부터 역삼까지 사람 많다고 생각했어요.
English: Really? I always thought there were a lot of people from Sadang to Yeoksam.
But even so, it's not as good as the Line 9 express train...

Korean: 쌤 이전에 다니시던 병원은 근무하는 인원이 많았어요?
English: Teacher, did the hospital you went to before have a lot of employees?

Korean: 부산에 다니던 병원은 인원이 많은 병원이었어요. 2층으로 운영되던 병원이었으니까요.
English: The hospital I used to go to in Busan was a very crowded hospital. It was a two-story hospital.

Korean: 직원이 많으면 친해지기 어려운 거 같아요.
English: I think it's hard to become close with a lot of employees.
I guess so.

Korean: 그래도 저는 나름 직급이 있었던 지라 다들 친해지려고 노력했었어야 했어요.
English: Still, since I had some level of rank, I should have tried to become friendly with everyone.

Korean: 직장인들 기준으로 하루에 집에서 보내는 시간보다 회사에 있는 시간이 많으니까 동료들하고 사이가 안 좋으면 곤란한 거 같아요.
English: For office workers, we spend more time at work than at home each day, so it would be difficult if we didn't get along with our coworkers.

Korean: 네 맞아요. 그리고 직급이 있는 사람일수록 관리를 해야 하니까 어느 정도의 친분은 필수죠.
English: Yes, that's right. And the higher the position, the more you have to manage, so a certain level of friendship is essential.
Because it makes it easier for me to handle the work.
Teacher, you changed fields.
What did people around you say?

Korean: 어차피 저의 장래니까 크게 뭐라 하는 사람은 없었어요. 하하
English: Since it was my future anyway, no one really said anything. Haha

Korean: 쌤은 아예 직업 자체가 속기사가 처음인 거예요?
English: Teacher, is being a stenographer your first job?

Korean: 네 그전에 다른 거 준비하다가 시간이 좀 지났어요.
English: Yes, some time passed while I was preparing something else before that.

Korean: 저는 처음부터 직업을 속기사로 정했다면 어땠을까 하는 생각도 드네요 하하
English: I sometimes wonder what it would have been like if I had decided to become a stenographer from the beginning haha
** How are you?
I'm satisfied now too.

Korean: 제가 전공을 잘못 정했다는 생각이 항상 있었는데 그 부분에 대한 갈증도 좀 해소되고요.
English: I always thought that I had chosen the wrong major, but my thirst for that has been somewhat quenched.

Korean: 저는 전공은 괜찮은데 직업을 잘못 선택했다는 생각이 들어서 항상 고민이었는데 속기사란 직업이 여자가 하기에는 나쁘지 않은 것 같아요!
English: I always worried that I chose the wrong career even though my major was okay, but it seems like being a stenographer isn't a bad job for a woman!

Korean: 작년에 출퇴근 프리랜서 속기사로 잠깐 일을 했었어요.
English: Last year, I worked briefly as a freelance stenographer, commuting to and from work.

Korean: 사람 심리가 웃겨요. 작업량만큼 페이 받는 시스템이었는데, 제가 돈에 눈이 멀어서 점점 쉬는 시간도 없이 일을 하고 있더라고요.
English: Human psychology is funny. It was a system where you get paid according to the amount of work you do, but I was so blinded by money that I started working without any breaks.

Korean: 지금 작업량은 익숙해져서 오히려 더 많지만 그래도 심리적으로 안정이 돼서 좋네요.
English: I'm used to the workload now, so it's actually more, but I'm still psychologically stable, so that's good.

Korean: 네 이게 심리적 안정감이 중요한 것 같아요.
English: Yes, I think psychological stability is important.

Korean: 마음이 급하면 오히려 일을 그르치게 되죠. 하하 여유도 중요한 것 같아요!
English: If you're impatient, you'll end up making mistakes. Haha. I think being relaxed is also important!

Korean: 앞으로 속기사로 계속 일은 하겠지만 저는 지금 회사가 나름대로는 첫 근무지라서 약간 어미 새처럼 좋거든요.
English: I will continue to work as a stenographer in the future, but this company is my first place to work, so I feel a bit like a mother bird.

Korean: 짝사랑이긴 하지만... 계속 일할 수 있으면 좋겠어요.
English: Even though it's unrequited love... I hope I can keep working.
** I wish the teacher was here too haha

Korean: 그러게요. 저도 여기가 괜찮은 것 같아요.
English: Yeah, I think it's okay here too.

Korean: 저도 어떻게 보면 여기에서 처음 일을 본격적으로 시작한 거니까! 같이 했으면 좋겠어요! 하하
English: In a way, this is where I first started working in earnest! I wish we could work together! Haha

Korean: 전에 티비에서 강철부대 잠깐 봤는데 거기 출연자들이 그때 아주 인기가 많더라고요?
English: I saw Steel Troops briefly on TV before, and the cast members were really popular back then, right?

Korean: 아 진짜요? 사실 제가 티비를 잘 안 봐서 잘 모르는데 그게 대충 어떤 내용이에요?
English: Oh really? Actually, I don't really know because I don't watch TV much, but what is it roughly about?

Korean: 제가 군대 체계를 잘 모르긴 하는데 특전사 출신이나 유디티? 암튼 특수부대원 출신들이 나와서 각 부대 이름 걸고 몸 쓰는 게임 하는 거 같았어요.
English: I don't know much about the military system, but it seemed like special forces or UDITs? or whatever, came out and played a game where they used their units' names to show off their skills.

Korean: 진짜 잠깐 봐서 잘 모르지만 출연자들이 인기가 많은지 기사도 많길래요.
English: I don't know much because I only watched it briefly, but there were a lot of articles about how popular the cast members were.

Korean: 박군인가...? 그 사람 되게 유명하던데 혹시 그 사람 강철부대에 나왔었나요?
English: Is that Mr. Park...? He's really famous. Did he appear in Steel Troops?
Oh right, that guy was there too.

Korean: 근데 그분은 트로트 불러서 유명한 것 같기도 해요.
English: But I think he's famous for singing trot.

Korean: 그분은 미우새 작업할 때 내용을 잠깐 들은 거밖에...
English: He only heard a little bit about the content while working on Miusae...

Korean: 하도 박군 박군 거려서 대체 누구인가 저도 찾아봤었네요.
English: I was so curious about Park Gun and Park Gun that I even looked up who he was.

Korean: 뭐 울산 가까이 살았던 거 같은데 키키
English: Kiki, I think you lived near Ulsan
When I think of UDT, I think of the Navy.
Was Judith a naval special agent?
I don't know, was it the Navy or the Marines...?

Korean: 아 우리 아빠 해병 출신이신데 별로 티는 안 내세요.
English: Oh, my dad was a Marine, but he doesn't really show it.

Korean: 해병들 그런 거 심하던데 아빠는 해병 얘기도 싫어하심...
English: Marines are so bad at that, but my dad hates talking about Marines...

Korean: 음... 아버지가 그런 거 별로 안 좋아하시는 것 같네요. 하하
English: Hmm... I don't think my dad likes that kind of stuff. Haha.
Marine Corps pride is awesome haha

Korean: 하도 얘기를 안 꺼내시니까 도대체 무슨 일이 있었던 거냐고 물어본 적도 있는데 키키
English: Since you never brought up the subject, I once asked you what on earth happened. Kiki

Korean: 진해 놀러 갔다가 술 취한 해군들하고 시비 붙어서 싸우다가 허리 디스크 나간 얘기만 종종 하시더라고요 키키
English: Kiki often talks about how he went to Jinhae to play and got into a fight with some drunken sailors and got into a herniated disc.
Oh really? Kiki

Korean: 왜 다들 술만 마시면 시비가 붙어 가지고 그렇게 사고를 치는지...
English: Why do people get into fights and cause accidents whenever they drink alcohol?

Korean: 군인 음주 폭행 시비가 생각보다 잘 일어나네요.
English: Military drunk driving incidents occur more often than you might think.

Korean: 아버지 세대는 더 옛날이니까 그런 일도 많았겠죠?
English: My father's generation lived longer, so there must have been a lot of such things, right?

Korean: 해군이랑 해병이랑 사이가 안 좋았다고 들었어요 지금은 어떤지 몰라요.
English: I heard that the Navy and Marines didn't get along well. I don't know what it's like now.

Korean: 똑같이 바다 지키는데 사이좋게 지킬 것이지... 키키
English: We're both protecting the sea, so we'll protect each other in a friendly way... Kiki

Korean: 아 진짜요? 사이가 나쁜 줄은 몰랐네요.
English: Oh really? I didn't know we were on bad terms.

Korean: 그러게요... 힘든데 사이좋게 지키면 더 좋을 텐데 하하
English: Yeah... It's hard, but it would be better if we kept in touch haha

Korean: 군대 경험자가 없다 보니 얘기할수록 궁금증만 커져가는...
English: Since I don't have any military experience, the more I talk, the more curious I become...

Korean: 저도 남자친구들한테밖에 얘기들은 게 없어서 이렇다 할 말이 없네요. 하하
English: I don't really have anything to say because I've only talked to my boyfriends. Haha

Korean: 한 분이 아닌 거 같은데 군대 다 기다리셨어요?
English: I don't think there's just one person, but did you wait for the entire military?
Wow... She's a girlfriend of will...
No, Kiki.

Korean: 한 명만 기다렸어요. 한 명을 좀 오래 사귀었던지라 키키
English: I waited for just one person. I've been dating one person for quite some time, so Kiki

Korean: 나머지는 다 다녀온 상태에서 만난 거예요.
English: The rest of us met after we had all been there.

Korean: 저는 아직 자격증이 없는데 이번에 꼭 붙고 싶지만 살짝 욕심을 놨어요.
English: I don't have a license yet, but I really want to get it this time, but I've let down my greed a little.
I wish I could get at least a 3rd grade license.

Korean: 저는 요번에 진짜 욕심 있어요 키키  진짜 따야해요...
English: I'm really greedy this time. I really have to get Kiki...
**Why are you so greedy, sir?

Korean: 욕심을 부려봤자 또 긴장해서 손 멈추고 그러면 어차피...
English: Even if you try to be greedy, you'll get nervous and stop, so anyway...

Korean: 그냥 연습 삼아 가 봤을 때처럼 아무 생각 않기로 했어요.
English: I decided not to think about it like I did when I just went there for practice.

Korean: 저도 긴장을 하지 말아야 하는데 아마도 따고 싶다는 압박감 때문이 아닐까 싶어요.
English: I shouldn't be nervous either, but I think it might be because of the pressure of wanting to win.
This time, I'm going to take a tranquilizer and go.

Korean: 저는 저번에 약국에서 안정액 5병 사서 시험 전에 5일 동안 같은 시간에 꼬박꼬박 먹었는데 별로 효과가 없었어요...
English: I bought 5 bottles of the tranquilizer from the pharmacy last time and took them at the same time every day for 5 days before the test, but it didn't really work...

Korean: 저도 약국에서 산 건 별로 효과를 못 봤어요.
English: I also didn't see much effect from the ones I bought at the pharmacy.

Korean: 저는 이번에는 병원에서 처방받는 약을 먹어보려고요. 테스트를 해봐야겠지만...
English: This time, I'm going to try taking the medicine prescribed by the hospital. I'll have to get it tested, though...

Korean: 제가 속기로 돈 번 지는 1년이 딱 됐는데 그동안 무자격 속기사였어서 키키  암튼 이번에는 좀 벗어나고 싶은 마음도 있고요...
English: It's been exactly a year since I started earning money through stenography, but I was an unqualified stenographer during that time, so I'm kind of looking to get away from it this time...

Korean: 저는 심지어 운전면허도 없어서 자격증이란 게 아예 없어요.
English: I don't even have a driver's license, so I don't have any qualifications at all.

Korean: 아 진짜요? 저는 자격증 있긴 있는데 속기계에서는 별로 쓸모가 없어서 하하
English: Oh really? I have a certificate, but it's not very useful on the stenographer haha

Korean: 혹시 속기 자격증 말고 또 따고 싶은 자격증 없으세요?
English: Are there any other certifications you would like to obtain other than the shorthand certification?
First of all, I need to drive urgently... and also...

Korean: 아, 자격증은 아닌데 언젠가는 애증의 토익 만점을 좀...
English: Oh, it's not a certificate, but someday I'll get a perfect score on the TOEIC test...

Korean: 아 토익... 저도 학교 다닐 때 토익 때문에...
English: Ah TOEIC... When I was in school, I also took TOEIC...

Korean: 진짜 토익 스트레스에서 벗어난 게 제일 좋네요. 하하
English: The best thing is that I'm free from the stress of TOEIC. Haha

Korean: 저는 컴퓨터 자격증을 따고 싶네요. 컴활
English: I want to get a computer qualification. Computer skills

Korean: 컴퓨터는 하다 보면 딸 거 같고 바리스타도 하나 있으면 좋을 거 같아요 키키
English: I think I'll get a computer eventually and it would be nice to have a barista too Kiki
I'm a computer... ha...

Korean: 저 컴맹이라서 진짜 필기 시험 볼 때 울면서 봤어요... 도대체 왜 이런 걸 외워야 하는 거냐면서
English: I'm so computer illiterate that I cried while taking the written test... Why on earth do I have to memorize this stuff?

Korean: 지금은 일반 2벌식 키보드를 쓰기가 힘들어서 아직 못 딸 거 같아요...
English: I don't think I'll be able to get it yet because it's hard to use a regular 2-set keyboard these days...

Korean: 저도 2벌식 키보드 다 까먹어서 워드 시험은 어떻게 할지 모르겠어요.
English: I also forgot the 2-set keyboard, so I don't know how to do on the Word exam.

Korean: 쌤 형제 자매 안 갖고 싶으세요?
English: Teacher, don't you want to have brothers and sisters?

Korean: 저는 형제 자매는 별로 생각해 본 적 없어요.
English: I never really thought about my brothers and sisters.

Korean: 저는 외동이 더 좋아서 하하 쌤은요?
English: I like only children better haha what about you teacher?
Have you ever thought about being an only child?

Korean: 저는 동생 있는 거 너무 좋아서 생각해 본 적 없어요 하하
English: I never thought about it because I love having a younger sibling so much haha

Korean: 저도 혼자가 좋아서 딱히 생각해 본 적이 없네요.
English: I also like being alone, so I've never really thought about it.

Korean: 혹시 만약에 결혼을 한다면 자녀 몇 명 가지고 싶다는 생각 하신 적 있으세요?
English: Have you ever thought about how many children you would like to have if you get married?

Korean: 저는 하나만으로도 벅찰 거 같아요. 사실 자녀 생각도 없긴 한데...
English: I think I'd be overwhelmed with just one. Actually, I don't even think about having children...
What about the teacher?

Korean: 저는 여건만 되면 둘은 낳고 싶어요 하하
English: I want to have two children if circumstances allow haha

Korean: 근데 여건이 안 될 것 같은 느낌이 들어서... 제 나이도 있고...
English: But I have a feeling that the conditions won't allow it... and I'm old too...
Ah... that's right...

Korean: 우리는 낳으려면 지금 빨리 낳아야 겨우 되는 거 아니에요?
English: If we're going to have children, don't we have to do it quickly now?
These days, people are giving birth even in their 40s...

Korean: 40대에도 낳을 수 있긴 있는데 그러면 제 몸이 힘들어지니까요. 하하
English: I could have a baby in my 40s, but it would be hard on my body. Haha.

Korean: 젊을 때 낳는 게 좋긴 좋은데 결혼이 많이 늦은 편이죠.
English: It's good to have children when you're young, but marriage tends to be quite late.

Korean: 근데 결혼하기 전까지 연애 기간도 있고 하니까...
English: But there is a period of dating before marriage...

Korean: 쌤은 연애 얼마나 하고 결혼하고 싶으세요?
English: Teacher, how long have you been dating before you want to get married?
I think it should take at least a year.

Korean: 이게 알고 지내던 사이에서 사귄 거라고 하더라도 남친일 때랑 친구일 때랑 많이 다르더라고요.
English: Even if we started dating after getting to know each other, it's very different when he's my boyfriend and when he's my friend.
What about you, teacher? If you are dating

Korean: 저는 1년은 통성명이나 겨우 했을 시기라고 농담처럼 얘기하는데... 저는 17년 정도 그냥 사귀고 있어서요...
English: I joke that I only had a year to make a formal statement... I've been dating for about 17 years...

Korean: 남의 일이라고 한다면 한 3년은 연애하면서 살아 보고 결혼하라고 하고 싶네요.
English: If it's someone else's business, I'd say live together in a relationship for about 3 years before getting married.

Korean: 3년... 음... 사실 그게 제일 베스트이긴 한데 이제 시간이 촉박하다 보니까 아무래도 1년으로 줄여야겠죠...? 하하
English: 3 years... um... actually that would be the best, but since time is running out, I guess I'll have to shorten it to 1 year...? haha

Korean: 그쵸~ 연애는 완전 사적인 영역인데 사람마다 다르고 상황도 다르고요.
English: Right~ Dating is a completely private area and it's different for everyone and every situation is different.

Korean: 주변에 최단 기간 결혼한 거 본 게 저는 첫 만남에 바로 애 만들고 배 부르기 전에 결혼한 우리 외삼촌...
English: The person I've seen get married the fastest around me is my maternal uncle who had a baby right after meeting her and got married before she was full.
Wow... You really did it with short-term properties.

Korean: 제 친한 동생도 6개월 만에 상견례 하고 결혼하더라고요.
English: My close friend also got married after meeting the parents within 6 months.

Korean: 소개팅 자리였는데 소개팅하는 날 그러기 쉽지 않잖아요?
English: It was a blind date, but it's not easy to do that on the day of a blind date, right?

Korean: 나중에 외숙모 출산할 때 날짜 계산해 보고 웃겨 죽는 줄 알았네요 키키
English: I thought I would die laughing when I calculated the date when my aunt gave birth later. Kiki

Korean: 외삼촌이 외숙모를 진짜 많이 사랑하고 마음에 들어 하셨나 봐요. 하하
English: I guess my uncle really loved and liked my aunt a lot. Haha

Korean: 첫눈에 그렇게 알아볼 수 있다면 얼마나 좋을까요 하하
English: How nice it would be if you could recognize it like that at first sight haha

Korean: 하하 첫눈에 반하는 거 어떻게 생각하세요?
English: Haha, what do you think about love at first sight?

Korean: 음... 첫눈에 반한다는 느낌이 뭔지는 모르겠는데 봤을 때 뭔가 꽂히는? 느낌이 오는 사람이 있다는 건 경험해 본 것 같아요!
English: Hmm... I don't know what it feels like to fall in love at first sight, but I think I've experienced someone who you just get a feeling for when you see them!

Korean: 첫눈에 반해 본 적이 없어서 무슨 느낌인지 모르겠네요 하하
English: I've never fallen in love at first sight before so I don't know what it feels like haha

Korean: 외모적인 부분이 빠질 수 없겠죠? 아무래도?
English: I guess the appearance aspect can't be left out, right? I guess?

Korean: 외적인 부분은 아무래도 스캔이 바로 끝나고 다른 걸 알아가지 않을까요? 하하
English: As for the external part, I think we'll find out other things right after the scan is finished, right? Haha

Korean: 쌤이 생각하시는 첫눈이라는 건 물리적으로 딱 처음 본 순간이 아닌가 봐요 하하
English: I think the first snow you're thinking of isn't the exact moment you physically see each other haha

Korean: 첫눈에 반한다는 느낌보다는... 뭔가 느낌을 설명을 못하겠는데... 스파크가 튄다? 저 사람 뭔가 느낌이 다르다? 이런 느낌이었어요. 하하
English: Rather than feeling love at first sight... I can't explain the feeling... sparks flying? That person feels different? It was like that. Haha

Korean: 그 사람을 봤는데 그 순간이 슬로우 모션처럼 보이는 순간도 있었고요.
English: I saw that person and there were moments when it seemed like it was in slow motion.

Korean: 진짜 딱 처음에 보자마자 저 사람이랑은 뭔가 될 거 같다 이런 건 없었어요?
English: Didn't you really think that something was going to happen between you and that person the moment you first saw them?

Korean: 저는 연애를 시작하는 단계를 해 본 게 십수 년 전이라서 기억이 잘...
English: I don't remember well because it's been over ten years since I started dating...

Korean: 처음에는 없었는데 지내면 지낼수록 뭐지? 뭐지? 이 사람 뭐지? 뭔데 이런 이상한 느낌이 들지? 이런 건 있었네요. 하하
English: At first, there wasn't any, but as time went by, I thought, "What is this? What is this person? What is this strange feeling?" I did have those things. Haha.

Korean: 그런 느낌이 저도 태어나서 처음이었어요. 정말 좋아하는 사람도 있었고 경험도 다 있었는데도요.
English: It was the first time in my life that I felt that way. Even though I really liked someone and had had many experiences.

Korean: 요즘은 삼귄다라고 하고 뭐 예전엔 썸탄다 이런 말도 있었잖아요.
English: Nowadays, people say "samgyunda", but in the past, there was also a word called "somtanda".

Korean: 애매모호한 상태? 그런 거 어떻게 생각하세요?
English: Ambiguous state? What do you think about that?

Korean: 저는 애매모호한 거 싫어요. 확실한 게 좋죠.
English: I don't like ambiguity. I like certainty.

Korean: 마음에 들면 일단 만나보고 생각해야죠. 하하 안 만나보고 그 사람을 어떻게 아나 싶어요.
English: If you like someone, you should meet them first and think about it. Haha, how can you know someone without meeting them?
** What about you?

Korean: 그게 반쯤 만나는 상태라고 하던데... 서로에게 의무만 없는 상태?
English: That's what they call a halfway meeting... a state where there are no obligations to each other?

Korean: 근데 그게 다 상처받는 게 두려워서 만들어낸 방어기제가 아닌가 싶어요. 상대방에게 그런 기간이 필요하다면 해야죠 뭐.
English: But I think that's all a defense mechanism created out of fear of getting hurt. If the other person needs that kind of time, then you should do it.

Korean: 음... 비겁하다는 생각도 들지만 한편으로는 과거에 어떤 상처를 받았길래 그럴까 싶기도 하더라고요.
English: Well... I think it's cowardly, but on the other hand, I wonder if it's because he was hurt in the past.

Korean: 만약에 이쪽은 상대방에게 확신이 있는데 상대방은 나에 대한 의무로부터 자유로운 기간이 필요하다고 하면 자존심은 상하겠죠.
English: If you have confidence in the other person, but they need a period of freedom from obligations to you, your pride will be hurt.

Korean: 요즘 사람들 잘 모르겠다... 나도 그 세대지만 MZ 세대 이해불가 하하
English: I don't really understand people these days... I'm from that generation too, but I don't understand the MZ generation haha

Korean: 음... 근데 그런 게 진짜 사랑하는 걸까요...?
English: Um... but is that really love...?
I think so.

Korean: 결국 어떤 부분이든 나는 책임지고 싶어 하지 않는 그런 느낌이네요.
English: Ultimately, I feel like I don't want to take responsibility for any part of it.

Korean: 결국에 유사 연애 좀 해 보고 진짜 연애하든지 말든지 결정하겠다는 건데...
English: In the end, I'm going to try some pseudo-relationships and then decide whether to date for real or not...

Korean: 그 부분이 안 맞는 사람하고는 애초에 시작조차 없겠죠 뭐 하하
English: I wouldn't even start with someone who doesn't fit in that area haha

Korean: 음... 뭔가 나하고 맞지 않는 건 감내하고 싶지 않다 이거네요. 하하
English: Hmm... I don't want to tolerate anything that doesn't suit me. Haha

Korean: 요즘은 확실히 뭔가 다르긴 다르네요. 결국 내가 먼저인?
English: These days, things are definitely different. In the end, it's me first?

Korean: 저는 베타 한 마리 키우는데 요즘 통 시간이 없어서 신경을 못 써 줬더니 꼬리 끝이 갈라진 게 보이더라고요...
English: I have a betta, but I haven't had much time to take care of it lately, and then I noticed that the tip of its tail is split...

Korean: 진짜요? 그거 영양 부족이라서 그런 걸 수도 있다고 하던데 혹시 영양제 주고 계세요?
English: Really? They say it could be due to malnutrition. Are you giving it any nutritional supplements?
Of course~ I'll give you some nutritional supplements too...

Korean: 근데 매일 조금씩 물을 갈아주다가 며칠에 한 번 많이 갈아줘서 애가 환수 스트레스가 있는 거 같네요.
English: But I changed the water a little bit every day and then changed it a lot once every few days, so I think the pet is stressed from changing the water.

Korean: 아... 그쵸. 물고기들 환수 스트레스 받는다고 하더라고요.
English: Oh... right. I heard that fish get stressed when they are returned to the water.
How do you get a refund?
What tool do you use to do this?
I use a dropper to scoop up the excrement one by one.
It's a beta so the tank is small.

Korean: 아하 저는 어항이 조금 크기가 있어서 환수 용품을 따로 사서 사용도 해봤는데 결국에는 그냥 통으로 옮겨서 환수해 줬었어요.
English: Aha, my fish tank is a bit big, so I tried buying and using water change products separately, but in the end, I just transferred the water to the container and changed it.
I really thought I was going to die...

Korean: 예전에 큰 어항이랑 새우항도 따로 하고 그럴 땐 환수할 엄두도 못 냈어요.
English: In the past, we had separate large fish tanks and shrimp tanks, and we couldn't even think of recovering them.

Korean: 그래서 최대한 환수 필요 없게 펌프도 많이 돌리고 틈만 나면 스포이드질하고 산소 많이 넣고...
English: So, I try to run the pump as much as possible to avoid having to refill, and whenever I have time, I use a dropper and add a lot of oxygen...

Korean: 보니까 어항에 빨판으로 흡착해서 어항 속에 미생물 찌꺼기? 청소 물고기! 그래 청소 물고기 있다고 하던데 혹시 걔네는 생각 안 해보셨어요? 하하
English: I see that they suck up the microbial waste in the tank with their suction cups? Cleaning fish! Yes, they say there are cleaning fish, have you ever thought about them? Haha
There was that too Kiki

Korean: 근데 그걸로 감당 안 되던데요... 그냥 걔도 감상용으로 키웠어요. 비파...
English: But I couldn't handle it... I just raised it for appreciation. Bipa...

Korean: 그렇군요. 저는 너무 관리가 힘들어서 걔네 키울까 생각했었는데 뭔가 또 새로운 일을 만들지 않을까 싶어서 포기했었죠. 하하
English: I see. I thought about raising them because they were too hard to manage, but I gave up because I thought they would create something new. Haha

Korean: 베타는 성격이 어때요? 구피하고는 좀 다르다고 하던데
English: What is Beta's personality like? I heard it's a bit different from Guppy's.
Beta is so pretty

Korean: 근데 무지 사나워서 한 마리만 키울 수 있어요. 수컷 두 마리 두면 죽을 때까지 싸워서...
English: But they are so ferocious that you can only raise one. If you keep two males, they will fight to the death...
Wow... Really?

Korean: 아 그러고 보니까 베타는 다른 종이랑 같이 키울 수 없다고 본 것 같아요.
English: Oh, now that I think about it, I think it's because I thought Betas couldn't be raised with other species.

Korean: 구피는 음... 새끼를 너무 많이 낳아... 키키
English: Goofy... um... has too many babies... Kiki

Korean: 맞아요 다른 애들도 합사하는 게 어렵죠.
English: That's right, it's hard for other kids to merge too.

Korean: 구피 키울 때는 처음에는 출산 임박한 암컷 일일이 부화통에 분리하다가 나중에는 그냥 살아남을 새끼만 남으라면서 그냥 뒀어요 너무 많이 낳길래 하하
English: When raising guppies, at first I separated the females that were about to give birth into hatching tanks one by one, but later I just left them, saying that I would leave only the ones that would survive. They gave birth to so many haha

Korean: 네 진짜 낳아도 너무 많이 낳아요. 그래서 자기 새끼 잡아 먹는 건가...
English: Yes, they really do give birth to too many. So they eat their own babies...

Korean: 잡아 먹으니까 살려줬었는데 내가 감당 불가능이라서 키키
English: I saved your life because you caught and ate it, but I couldn't handle it, so Kiki

Korean: 저는 새우를 다시 키우려고 기회를 보고 있는데 결국 집에 있는 시간이 많아야 그것도 할 수 있어서 당분간은 안 될 거 같아요 하하
English: I'm looking for an opportunity to grow shrimp again, but I don't think I'll be able to do that for a while since I have a lot of time at home haha

Korean: 새우는 진짜 신경 많이 써야 된다고 하더라고요.
English: They say that shrimp really require a lot of care.

Korean: 새우가 예뻐서 저도 잠시 알아봤었는데 그래서 그냥 포기했어요... 하하
English: The shrimp were pretty so I looked into it for a while, but then I just gave up... haha

Korean: 연어 낚시해 보고 싶어요. 뜬금없지만 연어 먹는 것도 좋아하고 낚시도 해 보고 싶고 해서 키키
English: I want to try salmon fishing. It's out of the blue, but I like eating salmon and I also want to try fishing, so Kiki

Korean: 키키  연어 낚시하니까 왜 나는 불곰이 생각나지...
English: Why does Kiki's salmon fishing make me think of a brown bear...

Korean: 저는 요새 여자 배구 보는 재미에 푹 빠졌네요. 지금 올림픽 4강까지 올라가서 너무 재밌어요.
English: I've been really into watching women's volleyball lately. It's so much fun now that they've made it to the Olympic semifinals.

Korean: 아 저는 한일전만 봤는데요 터키랑 경기는 얘기만 들었어요!
English: Oh, I only watched the Korea-Japan match, but I only heard about the match against Türkiye!

Korean: 선수도 두 명밖에 모르긴 하는데... 희진 선수랑 연경 언니 하하
English: I only know two players... Heejin and Yeonkyung unnie haha

Korean: 키키  갓연경... 진짜 멋진 사람... 배구 잘하는 건 말할 것도 없는데 리더십까지 있어.
English: Kiki God Yeon-kyung... She's a really cool person... Not only is she good at volleyball, she's also a great leader.

Korean: 남녀 선수 통틀어 세계 랭킹 1위라니 너무 멋진 것 같아요!
English: I think it's so cool that a male and female player is ranked number one in the world!

Korean: 사실 룰 잘 모르는데 쌤은 잘 아세요?
English: Actually, I don't know the rules very well, but do you know them, teacher?

Korean: 그냥 대충 넘겼다 아니다, 넘겼는데 선 밖이다 안이다 이런 거밖에 모르고 봐요 저는 키키
English: I just roughly passed it over. No, I passed it over, but I only know that it is outside the line and inside the line. I am Kiki.

Korean: 저 사실... 일반인 배구 동호회에 4년 있었어요... 키키  경기도 출전한 경험 있고요. 그래서 배구 좋아해요.
English: Actually, I was in a regular volleyball club for 4 years... and I even played in a Kiki match. So I like volleyball.

Korean: 팀 플레이의 재미를 느낀 게 바로 배구죠 크크
English: Volleyball is where I felt the fun of team play, haha

Korean: 아 맞다 하하 쌤 배구하셨다 그랬는데 어쩌다가 배구를 하게 됐어요?
English: Oh right haha, teacher you said you played volleyball, how did you end up playing it?

Korean: 배드민턴이나 테니스, 탁구 이런 거 하시는 분들은 좀 봤는데 배구는 처음 봐요
English: I've seen people playing badminton, tennis, and table tennis, but this is my first time seeing someone playing volleyball.

Korean: 제가 예전에 좋아했던 친구가 배구에 거의 미쳐서 사는 아이였는데... 걔한테 끌려갔죠 뭐...
English: I used to have a friend who was obsessed with volleyball... I was drawn to him...

Korean: 키가 커서 분명히 쓸모가 있을 거라고... 키키
English: I'm sure he'll be useful since he's tall... Kiki
